message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest dermatomyositis. Among the options, anti-Jo-1 antibodies are commonly found in patients with dermatomyositis. Anti-Sm antibodies are associated with lupus, anti-Scl-70 with systemic sclerosis, and anti-histone with drug-induced lupus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest dermatomyositis. Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are commonly found in dermatomyositis patients. Anti-Sm is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, anti-Scl-70 with systemic sclerosis, and anti-histone with drug-induced lupus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest juvenile dermatomyositis, which is associated with the anti-Jo-1 antibody. None of the other options are associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest the patient has dermatomyositis, and among the options, only Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are associated with this condition. Anti-Sm is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, while Anti-Scl-70 is associated with systemic sclerosis. Anti-histone is associated with drug-induced lupus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination are consistent with dermatomyositis, a connective tissue disease that affects skin and muscles. The presence of heliotrope rash, hyperkeratotic papules, and calcium deposits are specific for dermatomyositis. Elevated levels of serum creatine kinase indicate muscle damage. Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are commonly found in dermatomyositis patients, specifically those with the interstitial lung disease subtype. Anti-Sm, Anti-Scl-70, and Anti-histone antibodies are not associated with dermatomyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including muscle weakness, pain, arthralgia, and elevated creatine kinase levels suggests dermatomyositis. Among the options listed, Anti-Jo-1 is most commonly seen in dermatomyositis patients. Anti-Sm is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, Anti-Scl-70 with systemic sclerosis, and Anti-histone with medication-induced lupus.

The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest dermatomyositis, and among the options, Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are commonly found in dermatomyositis. Anti-Sm antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, anti-Scl-70 antibodies are associated with systemic scleroderma, and anti-histone antibodies are associated with drug-induced lupus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest juvenile dermatomyositis. Among the options, only Anti-Jo-1 antibody is associated with polymyositis/dermatomyositis.
